title.title: Friendly Networks
The Journals of Our Beloved Friend John Hunt

msIdentifier.institution: Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College

projectDesc.p: The journals of Quaker minister John Hunt are stored at the Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College. With the generous support of H. David and Joyce E. Hunt, Library staff scanned and transcribed the journals, and in 2021, encoded the text in TEI. The 2021 project also included researching individuals mentioned in the text to create and update records about them in the Social Networks and Archival Context website

editorialDecl.p: John Hunt was a good writer, but like most 18th century authors, his punctuation, spelling, and abbreviations were not standardized or necessarily consistent. The goal of the Hunt project was to produce a text accessible to the modern reader, retaining all the words in the order they appear, but with added punctuation and capitalization to make the document readable. Some spelling of surnames and places has been corrected in order to facilitate searching. Any other additions supplied to aid the reader are surrounded by brackets. Archaic forms and spellings of words are also retained. “How art thou feeling” remains as written, not changed to “How are you feeling.” The word “sic” means that word or words are transcribed as written. Usually this marks an error in the original text. When identified by the editor, biblical references, all from the King James version, have been identified in notes. Where Hunt himself identified them as such this attribution is retained in the main body of the text.

Hunt consistently used Quaker-style plain dating, avoiding the names of the months and the names of days of the week. “Monday, October 9th,” for instance, is written as “Second Day, Ninth of the Tenth Month.” The headings dividing the texts were added by the editors, using the standard names for the months, again for ease of reading.

Hunt had a practice of regularly adding to a series of bound journals when he was at home, but usually recorded entries while he was at Yearly Meeting or travelling in the ministry on single sheets of paper. In publishing the entirety of the journal we have added “loose” sections where they fit chronologically.

Went to our meeting. Was youth's meeting. Isaac Andrews was there and spoke very notably. He signified a sympathy with someone present that was left so poor that they had hardly strength to keep awake, yet spoke encouragingly and said it was in order that they might be thoroughly proved and spoke very closely to the youth at the close of the meeting. Advised them to frequently read the Holy Scriptures and the experienced others of Friends' books. He reminded us of the text? Woe to the crown of pride and to the drunkards he spoke very closely.Isaiah 28:1? I thought we seemed to have a very extraordinary meeting.

Went to Monthly Meeting. Hannah Foster was there and spoke very notably and particular to someone concerning their reasoning and reasoning and suffering with the seed and said if we were willing to suffer we should in his time reign, and advised not to keep that back that belonged to the church, whether in discipline or more weighty matters.
div.note: Very poor till Hannah Foster spoke and after I had a very satisfying meeting which tended to some encouragement.

div.p: Went down to John Huggins's to take a colt to pasture.
Went to Abraham Matlack's to mend his cheese press in the morning and he came with me to shear sheep in the afternoon.

Was First Day. Went to our meeting. James Thorington of Pennsylvania was there and spoke exceeding notably. I thought he spokes very close encouragingly and clear to my state and had to believe he did to divers others' states. He said he thanked God that there was some souls visited that day. I thought we seemed to be favored with a very fine good meeting.
div.note: very poor at first yet had a very satisfactory meeting at last

div.p: Went to the Quarterly Meeting at Salem. James Thorington had a great deal to say again and several others appeared very notably. Lodged at Robert Wilson's near the meeting house. Went to the Yearly Meeting at Salem. James Thorinton was very large and notable. Came to John Ballinger's to lodge near Piles Grove.
div.note: A pretty hard thundershower
A Very Poor Dull Time With Me

div.p: Went to the youth's meeting at Piles Grove. Mathew Howill, a young man from Philadelphia spoke very prettily and James Thorington was very large again. I was pretty much shut up in many of these meetings though I believe it was best for me to be there and that it was a time of favor to many, being favored with a very powerful lively ministry in every meeting. After this meeting at Piles Grove we came home. I was taken very unwell on the road.
div.note: A very instructing time with me.

Went to our meeting. George Dillwyn was there and had pretty deal to say and it seemed to me the last time he appeared was chiefly for me. He advised us not to despise the day of small things the kingdom of heaven was compared to a grain of mustard seed Luke 13:19, Matthew 13:31, Mark 4:31 etc. and the fearful and unbelieving was to have their portion with hypocrites and advised to faithfulness in small things.

Went to our meeting appointed for John Churchman from Pennsylvania and we were favored with a most precious meeting. He spoke very encouragingly to some present and very affectionately to us all. He hinted of some that might be nearer their latter end than they were aware of, he advised us not entertain hard thoughts of one another. They that did he said entertained enemies of Christ.
div.note: favored a very Good meeting incouraging instructting conserving time with me

Went to our meeting. Hannah Foster was there whose words seemed to me very remarkable. She said she thought she could not be easy without mentioning a sympathy with some present who were under great exercise about laboring in the church. Said their labor though small might be of more service than they were aware of. Coming from such or such a one it might be like bread cast upon the waters that might be gathered after many days, Ecclesiastes 11:1 and mentioned something what a pity it would be if the Lord should be disappointed of his servants. It seemed to strike me having great reason to think it was for me.

After this meeting was over a committee appointed from our Monthly Meeting stayed to gather to consider the case of those children amongst us whose parents one had a right and the other none, who unanimously agreed that we ought to observe the words of the minute of the Yearly Meeting made in the year 1772. It was a very satisfactory time with me.
At work at Thorn's.

I went to Haddonfield meeting. Rachel Linsey appeared in testimony and old Ephraim Tomlinson appeared under a great exercise. He said he had the closest longest trial that ever he had in all his life but the Lord had shewed him favor, which he spoke of in a solemn manner. He seemed uncommonly exercised and got up several times and said to us that may have to speak to the people let us not be too forward nor too backward but if it is laid upon us to speak let us do it in the best manner we can. This he repeated twice over.
About home getting timber for Joseph Morgan's applemill.

At ditto. I heard of the death of Joseph Smith's wife which put me in mind of John Churchman's words when at our meeting. Note the 25th of the Sixth Month back.

I went to our quarterly meeting. Robert Walker from Old England was there whose testimony was very searching lively and large. Susannah Lightfoot and Isaac Andrews appeared in prayer very notable. A lively meeting.
div.note: Dull at first. At last I thought was favored to partake with th had a fews words to say in meeting of business which several Friends expressed a satisfaction

div.p: About home cleaning out the well etc.
I went to our meeting. Josiah White was there.
I went down to the yearly meeting. Was at the Bank Meeting. divers young Friends appeared and M Se A the R. Went to Pine Street Meeting. Began business about the 3 hour afternoon.

I went to the Bank Meeting again where divers very notable testimonies was born and one especially by a woman friend from Old England was very powerful and affecting. Afternoon meeting of business came on again. Many weighty matters was wisely treated of and divers extraordinary epistles were read and I thought it was a time of great instruction and encouragement to many.

I attended Meeting of Business again this evening I went to see my well beloved friend John Parrish where there was a pretty company of Friends. Divers very lively testimonies was delivered and I thought Abraham Griffe spoke very encouraging it was to hear him tell the exercise he had passed through in his youth.
We met again at 5 o'clock and business was concluded about 10 o'clock at night. Joseph White appeared in prayer very lively and affecting at the conclusion.

I came home on foot in company with Jonas Cattle and found my family well which was very satisfactory. The boys made a pump for Joseph Champion 19 feet long and for brother Robert 16 feet long while I was gone to these meetings.
About home cleaning the well etc.
I went to our meeting.

div.p: About home turning and I went to Jude Clements's to doctor a pump.
Husking corn etc.
Hauling corn etc.
I went to our monthly meeting. Ann Gaunt and Elizabeth Morris was there. Both spoke very notably. Ann Gaunt was exceeding large in her testimony.
div.note: A very good meeting. I thought satisfactory time.

div.p: At home trimming casks etc.
Making cider; went over the creek to Joseph Buzby's. Took my wife and children.
Went to Ancocas meeting. Elizabeth Morris and John Sleeper was there both appeared very edifying. Went to Aaron Wills's after meeting lodged there all night.

We went to Ancocas Meeting appointed for Comfort Hoage and her companion the old woman I thought appeared in the most lively and most affecting manner that I had heard anybody in a great while. She spoke very encouraging to them that were young in the ministry there being divers of them there. She said would to God that all the Lord's people were prophets: who shall dare say to these hold their peace if these should hold their peace the stones would cry out,Luke 19:40 though their offering should seem but like a pair of turtle doves or two young pigeons.Leviticus 14:22. Went to Joseph Buzby's to dine after meeting and came home this evening.

We went to our meeting appointed for Comfort Hoage and her companion. Her companion spoke three times and that very well. The last time she directed her words to someone in particular and spoke very encouraging though they might be tossed as with a tempest yet if they held on they would make a most glorious and happy end and death would have not terrors over them. Comfort also appeared very deeply concerned that we might grow and know an increase in the truth. Benjamin Swett from Burlington also spoke twice, the last time was to the Negroes in particular. Comfort appeared very notable in prayer.
I went to Noah Garwood's to make three pumps. One was 20 feet long, one 16 feet long and one 14 feet long. The one 16 was for a schoolhouse.

I went to Monthly Meeting. Hannah Foster spoke very notably. She said she thought she could hardly make her friends sensible of the difficulty she apprehended there was in speaking in our meetings, either to our business or in the way of the ministry. She said we should travel as in the deeps that we might bring memorials from thence. My sister-in-law Esther pass meeting.

I went to Evesham Meeting appointed for Mary Lever from Old England and she had a great deal to say. At first she recommended honesty as the best policy and was particular in speaking to the over diffident and unbelieving and cautioned us not to put forth a hand to steal in times of poverty but patiently wait for breaking of bread.

div.note: I S A T Wi U h J N V S

div.p: I went to Jacob Hollinshead's to do something at his pump.
About home.
I went home with my sister Hester Hooton.

We went to Evesham Youth's Meeting. Hannah Foster preached and prayed very notably. Joshua Evans also spoke a considerable time and I thought well of the purpose. I thought we were favored with a very fine meeting.
I went to Joshua Lippincott's to fetch my pump tools home and making a little pump for brother Robert 8 feet long.
I went to Abel Lippincott's to do something at a old pump.
div.note: very exceedingly cold

div.p: I went to our meeting. Benjamin Sharpless was there from Philadelphia and intimated he had a mind to come home with me he being on foot and a very stormy day there seemed no way convenient for it. The next evening we eve[n?] happened to meet at Joseph Roberts quite unexpectedly he again signified he would have me stay the evening and that he wanted a little of my company. We had not sat long before he seemed uncommonly exercised and at last began to speak and I was satisfied it had the true sound and right relish of truth. His words was the word of the Apostle verse: if any man lack wisdom let him ask it of God James 1:5 and so on very prettily and mentioned Soloman asking for wisdom that he might know how to go out and come in before the people.1 Kings 3: 7 ...I am but a little child: I know not how to go out or come in
div.note: I had not heard that B. Sharpless had appeared that way before which word had been frequent in my mind about that [last line of text illegible].

div.p: I was about home.
I went to John Stone's to hew a pump.
I went to our meeting the time John Maxfield was married. Hannah Foster was there and was favored with a very lively testimony.
I went to Thomas Stokes's to mend pump had a very troublesome time with it.
At ditto.

I went to our meeting Isaac Andrews was there and spoke powerful and affecting and very encouragingly to us and spoke powerful and we were undoubtedly favored with a very extraordinary meeting. He told us to treasure up such visitations.
div.note: A stormy day

div.p: About home making a wood sled for myself.
Ditto ditto.
Ditto.
Getting firewood and went to our preparative meeting which was considerably satisfactory in the end
Went to hew a pump for Charles French.
I went down to Burough's mill.

Was First Day we went to our meeting. John Sleeper was there and he was favored in almost an uncommon manner and had a great deal to say. His first words was how much owest thou to My Lord and most exceeding notable sermon he made. We went to Joseph Warrington's in the afternoon.
I went to John Stone's to make a pump 17 feet long.
At ditto. Finished and came home.
About home.
I went to our Monthly Meeting which was some easement to my mind. Hannah Foster appeared in a lively manner.
I went to French's to make a pump was called home.
I went to mend a floor at John Roberts's.
Went to our meeting which was somewhat agreeable.

I went down to Haddonfield Monthly Meeting. Joshua Evans spoke very notably concerning the refiners fire and the fullers soap. Malachai 3:2 For who may abide the day of his coming, and who shall stand when he appeareth, for he is like a refiner's fire, and like fullers' soap.
I went to work at the pump at French's.
Went to Caleb Evans' with my wife in the sleigh.
Went to our meeting.
div.note: Not So Poor As a Some Times

div.p: Went down to Philadelphia to the burial of my wife's aunt Hannah Bissel, sister to father Warrington.
About home
Went to our meeting.

div.p: Went to finish that pump at French's place 24 feet long.
About home turning etc.
I went down to Jacob Stokes's to hew a pump.
I went to our meeting.

At do finished and came home.

Went to our meeting. Benjamin Swett was there said a good deal, study to be quiet and mind thine own business was his first words. This afternoon I went with some Friends, Joshua Roberts and his wife and Edmn Holingshead and Hannah French to visit some who were in the neglect of attending meetings which was something satisfying to me though no prospect of their amendment in them.
I went over Burlington Quarterly Meeting which I thought was instructing though a poor time with me. George Dillwyn spoke very lively.
I went to John Stone's to hew timber for a barn. It rained.
About home making a plow for Hugh Cowperthwaite.
My wife and I went to preparative meeting which was somewhat satisfactory

div.p: I went to Samuel Stokes's to make a top piece.
At do finished and came home.
Was First Day went to our meeting
I went to John Stone's to hew a frame for his barn.
At do

div.p: About home I went to Abraham Allen's to meet the Overseers of the Town and to take the Overseers of the Poor's office myself.
I went to Monthly Meeting. Hannah Foster prayed notable.
div.note: I Gave Up To Speak Again with Which I was not Dissatisfied

div.p: About home went to Job Cowperthwaite's after corn.
Went to mill and hewed a pump for Thomas Middleton.
Went to our meeting; an epistle was read.

div.p: I went down to Woodbury for a pair of wheels and was at Haddonfield Monthly Meeting. Isaac Andrews was there and spoke very notably about taking heed to the dictates of truth.
At home

I went to meet the overseers and representatives of the town at A. Allen's.
Went to our meeting.
Was Yearly Meeting at Philadelphia I was at a stand about going. My wife seemed unwilling and I gave it out.
About home plowing for oats.
Plow for oats.

At Stone's.

div.p: J. Warrington's. Met with some trials with my boys.
I went to John Stone's to work at the barn.
At ditto under temptations and provocations.
At ditto.

At ditto. I went to our youth's meeting. Jacob Andrews was there and spoke very notably I thought and Hannah Foster also spoke in a very lively manner. Thomas Evans also appeared and I thought we seemed to be favored with a very lively fine meeting.
div.note: not so poor as sometime past I Gave Up Say Something And felt a great deal better I T a time of favor I really think

div.p: At work at Stone's barn.
At ditto. Raised the barn and a very clever raising I think we had.
Went to our meeting.

Ditto.

A very stormy cold snowy morning.
About home
Went to our Monthly Meeting

div.p: I went down to Joseph Warrington's and below there to get a pine for for a schoolhouse at Moorestown.
About home planting corn and my wife very unwell.

At ditto.

A remark: Learn to hold thy tongue, five words cost Zacharious 40 weeks silence. Luke 1:5-22.
I went down to Upper Greenwich meeting. A very poor dull time.
Went to Salem Quarterly Meeting. Robert Voluntine and divers other very notable Friends was there.
Lodged at Joseph Brick's
div.note: A Dull Poor Time With Me

div.p: At Salem Yearly Meeting. David Ferris appeared very extraordinary favored with a good ministry

Came up to Piles Grove Youth's Meeting. Had a very solid good lively meeting. Went Benjamin Lippincott's to dine in company with Lucus Gil. At dinner I thought it my duty to say a few words to which I gave up and seemed satisfied.
Came home I went to our meeting and gave up to speak twice and Rebekah Roberts and we had a very satisfactory meeting. I put a pump in 8 feet long at the schoolhouse after meeting.
I went to John Risdin's to make a pump 25 feet long.
div.note: very much favored this day

div.p: I was obliged to attend a town meeting, which was disagreeable with the company being very light and frothy. It seemed to be a day of trial with me; but I was favored to come up with a degree of satisfaction. I being somewhat reserved and still a wicked man there seemed offended with me for it and asked why I sat studying my sermon which did not at all disturb me at that time. The magistrate seemed to pick at me but I was preserved out of their reach at that time.The published journal gives a slight different reading for the passage above: asked why I sat there, hanging my head, and told the people he reckoned I was studying my sermon. Some of the magistrates seemed also to pick at me. But this did not disturb me at all, and I was preserved out of their reach at that time.
Went to our meeting.
div.note: I appeared more composed strengthened today

div.p: Went to Job Coles to mend a cheese press.
About home shearing sheep etc.
div.note: X

div.p: Making a harrow for P. Mintle and went to seek after some stray sheep at Syllania Evans'. At this time there was a melancholy aspect on the trees of the woods and fruit trees, they being eaten bare with the caterpillars. In many places and in many places the frost killed the leaves so that it looked as if there had been a fire in the woods.
Went to our meeting – I A P Again and after meeting I went to John Risdin's to finish his pump and .
At Edmund Hollinshead to mend his old pump etc. Came home.
At home making a plow for Job Cowperthwaite.
Went to our meeting.
div.note: and Said A few Words Again

div.p: About home finishing a plow etc.
I went to market with my wife.
div.note: very dull and heavy Time With me

div.p: Went to our meeting. R. Roberts spoke very pretty expressed concern that we must become like the wi.
I went to John Stone's to work.
I went to sell some stray sheep a Syllania Evans's d so steady.
I went to our meeting.
div.note: a very dull heavy time with me

div.p: I went to John Stone's to shingling his barn.
At do and went to a raising of a barn for Ed French.
div.note: Came off with a good Begaf[?]

div.p: At home at work at a plow for Job Roberts.

Went to our Monthly Meeting. William Brown from Philadelphia and John Reeves from Cohansy was there and they spoke very notably. Shall they that love the Lord the E Johns first I thought it Seemed r for the elderly.

Went to our meeting appointed for John Reeves and he had a great deal to say. He spoke exceedingly encouragingly to us. Expressed a great satisfaction the he saw the Lord was raising up testimony bearers and that he was thankful for the feeling he felt amongst us. Hannah Foster also spoke very notably and encouragingly and said we need not be unacquainted with the voice a call of truth if we did but seek and wait to know it.
div.note: But a poor time with me a good deal out of joint somehow missed it in several little matters.

div.p: I went to move old woman that was on the town to Noah Haines's.
I went to our meeting. Rebekah Roberts spoke.
div.note: S B I A G X

div.p: Making a plow for William Rudrow.
About home looking at some sheep the dogs had killed.
I went to Thorn's to work.
Went to our meeting.
At Thorn's again.
At home plowing corn.
Went to our meeting.
At home plowing corn.
Ditto.
I went to Thomas Thorns to lay a corn floor and make cover.
I went to our meeting and went to John Stone's to work.
div.note: Re Pa M A I though I

div.p: At Stone's finishing the barn.
At home planting some potatoes etc.
Went to our meeting.
div.note: Rebekah Roberts Spoke again

div.p: At home reaping.
Ditto ditto.
Went to mowing.
Went to our preparative meeting.
div.note: Not So Poor as at some times I S A P D N th Ba

div.p: At home mowing.
Ditto ditto. Went to Elisha Hooton's and Isaac Borton's. I borrowed Thomas Story's Journal. Thomas Story, A Journal of the Life of Thomas Story Newcastle upon Tyne: Isaac Thompson, 1747.
I went to Evesham Meeting had a very hard dull poor time.
About reaping a very wet time.
Mow, harrowing corn.
Mowing a very wet time. A most dreadful hard thundershower.
Went to Evesham Monthly Meeting which was silent though some satisfactory in the end.
At home about hay.
Ditto ditto.

Went to our meeting. Isaac Andrews was there and preached and prayed very extraordinary. I thought it a very great favor to us. He spoke very encouragingly to the sincere seekers with whom he signified a near sympathy with their enquiring minds after this manner by whom shall Jacob arise for he is small and Amos 7:2 He had to say to such fear not worry Jacob though thou pass through? the fire it shall not kindle on thee or this the water it shall not overwhelm thee, but spoke very smart and close to the ca. It was a dull heavy time with me though I believe it was a lively meeting to many
About hay.
Ditto.
Ditto.
I went to Evesham which was very small dull and heavy yet I said a few words concerning sacrificing our time our nets and to our Dr .
Went to our meeting a very Poor Dull Heavy Time With Me. I found an account in the life of Thomas Story, page 221 and part in 224 as follows:

In the year 1699 many being taken away at Philadelphia by a pestilential fever then greatly prevalent ten being buried in one day and four died on the same several of them being good Friends. In page 224, he says my companion and I both remained in the town till the 23 of the month visiting the sick Friends from time to time as we found necessary or expedient, and great was the presence of the love of God with his people in the midst of this trying visitation which gave us occasion to say, good is the Lord and greatly to be feared, loved and obeyed for though he suffer afflictions to come upon his own chosen people in common with other men yet that which otherwise would be intolerable is made as nothing by how much sense thereof is swallowed up and immersed in his divine love, O the melting love! O the immortal sweetness I enjoyed with several as they lay under the exercise of the devouring evil, though unspeakably comforted in the Lord. Let my soul remember it and wit low before the Lord to the end of my days!

Great was the majesty and hound of the Lord! Great was the fear that fell upon all flesh! I saw no lofty or airy countenance; nor heard any vain jesting to move men to laughter; nor witty repartee, to raise mirth, nor extravagant feasting to excite the lusts and the desires of the flesh above measure: but every face gathered paleness and many hearts were humbled and countenances fallen and sunk as such that waited every moment to be summoned to the bar and numbered to the grave.

But the just appeared with open face and walked upright in the street and rejoiced in secret that perfect love that casteth out all fear and sang praises to him who liveth and reigneth and is worthy forever being resigned unto his holy will in all things, saying let it lie as thou will in time and in eternity now and forever. Nor love of the world nor fear of death could hinder their resignation, abridge their confidence or cloud their enjoyments in the Lord.
This companion of his died in Philadelphia with the fever.
I was about home mowing.
To ditto. getting in oats etc.
Finishing a plow.

I went to Evesham Youth's Meeting Isaac Andrews was there and John Sleeper. John was silent but Isaac had a great deal to say he expressed a sympathy with someone that was tried with a spirit of drowsiness a heaviness but spoke very encouragingly to them and said it was in order to prove us.
div.note: I spoke first in this meeting against an indolent and rambling spirit then Hannah Foster and then Thomas Evans appeared. I was under a good deal of concern after the meeting and fear I was not right in speaking and it continued for several days, though I to think what Isaac my condition pretty .

div.p: I went to make a plow for Thomas Middleton.
About home.

At our meeting. Rebekah Roberts spoke and myself a few words with which I seemed well satisfied. I went down to Haddonfield afternoon meeting. Joshua Evans spoke very well I though and I was under a good deal of exercise about speaking but being afraid I should be too forward I put it off even till the meeting broke up.
Plowing corn etc.
Ditto.
Hauling stuff of the new ground.
I went to our preparative meeting which was somewhat encouraging and satisfactory. I spoke again and seemed satisfied.
Harrowing corn
I went to Sr. Burrough's to mend his old pump.
Went to our meeting which was quite silent though agreeable. Benjamin Sharpless was there.
Went to John Stone's to work hewing timber for his kitchen.
At ditto very warm weather.
At ditto ditto.
I went to Monthly Meeting.
div.note: and I said so much to the business I was afraid I overdid it though I thought these seemed a necessity

div.p: I went to John Hinchman's to make a pump 24 feet long.
At do finished and came home.
Was First Day we went over the creek to meeting which was silent and Very Poor. Dined at Aaron Wills and went to J. Buzby's to lodge.
Went to Burlington to see sister E. Haines and came home this evening.
Went to J. Stone's to work at the kitchen.
Went to our meeting.
div.note: Very Poor indeed and dull

div.p: About home unwell.
Taking Indian physic.
div.note: Joshua Evans and I went to see Ed Weaver and a very satisfactory encouraging time worth remembering

div.p: Went to our meeting I thought was somewhat better. Went with Joshua Roberts and Edmond Hollinshead to see Sam Conrow and Thomas Hackney after meeting to little satisfaction. J. Lippincott was with us.
div.note: I Had A few Words to Say and R Robert spoke very prettily

div.p: At work at home at the new ground.
At ditto.
Making a plow for John Pine.

Went to our meeting. Joshua Gibbs was there and spoke a few words concerning an easy state which I thought very well of and had a sense of the necessity of striving against such a state. His sister Rebekah Wright was also there and bang'd us along right smartly.
div.note: In the forepart of the meeting and mentioned something concerning the inhabitants of Laish and the secure Zidonias that dwelt secure and at ease.Judges 18:7 Then the five men departed, and came to Laish, and saw the people that were therein, how they dwelt careless, after the manner of the Zidonians, quiet and secure

div.p: I went to make a top piece for William Vinicomb's pump 14 feet long.
At ditto.
Went to our meeting very poor. Went with E. Hollinshead and J. Roberts and John Lippincott to see Thomas and Isaac Lippincott concerning their misconduct to some satisfaction.
At home making pump boxes.
Went to W. Vinicomb's to make a pump in the meadow 12 feet long.
At ditto. Very rainy weather.
Went to our meeting very poor times with me. Rebekah Roberts spoke.
About home putting a beam in Jonas Cattle's plow and getting a piece of rye sowed.
I went to Jacob Wells's to mend his pump and was Elisha Hooton's and Isaac Borton's.
Was First Day. I went to our meeting.
div.note: Not so Poor as at Some Times I Said A few Words with Which I Seemed Pretty Well Satisfied

div.p: I went to John Stone's to work.
At ditto.
At home making a plow for Joseph Burroughs.
Went to our preparative meeting.
div.note: Brother Robert affairs concerning selling his Negro was moved and gave me a Good Deal of Unease for Several days

div.p: At home threshing and went to meet the overseers and representatives of the town at A. Allen's.
At home about some small matters.

Was First Day. I went to our meeting Hannah Foster was there and spoke very very notably and edifying. After meeting she came down to Colestown to see Edward Weaver who seemed to be near his end but was glad to see us and Hannah spoke very notably and affecting. Joshua Roberts his wife was there a comforting encouraging time. I sat up with him that night and he seemed to alter and grow worse as if he was just dying about midnight and continued struggling as if every hour would be his last till the Fourth Day following about 11 o'clock and died.
I was about home and several times with E. Weaver.
I went to mill at Haddonfield.
At Morten's with Edward Weaver who was sensible till near the last.
I went to Monthly Meeting and making a coffin for Edward Weaver.
Went to the burial and Joshua Evans was there and spoke very notably.

My wife and children went to Elisha Hooton's and to Isaac Borton's and up in the Barrens to get cranberries. William Bates was there and we killed a deer and got cranberries enough though I thought it seemed lost time to me.
I went to our meeting very drowsy and R Roberts spoke very well which I thought did good but I was all to pieces for my part being hurt with some Monthly Meeting business that was in confusion.
I went to John Stone's to work at a screw cider press.
At ditto.
Ditto.
Ditto. I went to our meeting.
div.note: Very Poor Dull Time

div.p: I went to Seth Lippincott's to hew a pump.
I went to J. Stone's to work again.
I went to our meeting which was silent and Very Poor.
I went to John Stone's and we raised the kitchen sic.
At work at ditto.
Ditto.
Ditto.

I went to Quarterly Meeting at Haddonfield. Robert Walker and Elizabeth Robinson and Mary Lever from Old England was there. Robert and Elizabeth both spoke very extraordinary and that the chief part of their testimony was against an inordinate love of the world. We were favored with a very good meeting. I thought it did me good.
About home turning some casks etc.
I went to our meeting.
div.note: and S S W I W R D A

dateline.date: 26 of the Ninth Month 1774 and 2 Day of the week.

div.p: I went down to Philadelphia Yearly Meeting and went to the Bank Meeting House which was pretty much shut up in the afternoon. About 3 o'clock began business at the meeting house in Pine Street. I attended this Yearly Meeting by adjournments till the Seventh Day following. In the afternoon about 2 o'clock adjourned to meet again at four. I having taken a bad cold was unwell and came home. The case concerning the Negroes wasJournal gives occasioned in place of was, 224. I thought the most closest exercise of anything that came before the meeting. I thought it the most solid meeting that ever I was at and a very large number of youngish people appeared very zealous and promising. At this time I was favored to see I was greatly behindhand and that I had suffered great loss for want of true stillness and keeping love and humble enough and by not keeping in a right spirit when talking with some about our Monthly Meeting business. By this I saw I was in danger of being quite lost, but I desire to ever remember it and take better for the future. Journal gives hope to take better care for the future, 224. We had a very pretty sitting one evening at Antony Morris's. Thomas Bulard and a woman Friend was notable. Dined one day at James Pemberton's. Robert Walker and his companion Morris Birbeck was there. Morris told me it was his lot to be much with my cousin William Hunt in Old England and that he was with him in Germany and he was with him at his last moments. Robert Walker spoke at the table and his discourse was very agreeable, telling us that he had seen George Fox his house and his cane and William Dewsberry's house and cane. Their conversation was pleasant.
I went to our meeting.
div.note: Not So Dull As At Some Time / Spoke Again

div.p: I went to Thorn's to mend an apple mill
Went Seth Lippincott's to make a pump 34 feet long.
At ditto.
I went to Monthly Meeting. Hannah Foster was lively in her testimony and the meeting somewhat satisfactory.
Went to Lippincott's to finish the pump.
About home doing something at my own pump.
I went to Evesham meeting.
div.note: and had something to say with which I felt pretty well satisfied afterwards and an open free cheerfulness

div.p: Husking corn.
Ditto.
Ditto.
Went to our meeting. Rebekah Roberts spoke very prettily and her words was in part the very same with mine at Evesham the week before concerning a search with lighted candles.
Husking corn and went to a vendue of cattle.
Getting in winter apples.
I went to our meeting which seemed pretty well I A G at Rebekah Roberts agains but little.
At home hauling corn.
At ditto.
I went to John Stone's to work.
I went to our Youth meeting. Isaac Andrews was there and preached and prayed very notably and Hannah Foster was pretty lively in the ministry but it was a very poor time with me.
At John Stone's to work.
Went down to Philadelphia with thoughts of buying a Dutch servant.
Went to our meeting but it was a very poor time with me I having this week met trouble and difficulty and provocation with one of my boys and I wrr'd him away.
Went to work at John Stone's.
At ditto.
Ditto.
Went to our meeting. Thomas Say from Philadelphia and his wife elderly though young in the ministry both appeared and very edifying and lively.
div.note: Very Poor Time with me

div.p: At work at Stone's.
At ditto.
Sarah Hopkins spoke and I was under some exercise to appear but put it off through doubt first but afterward thought it might have been best to have left what was on my mind.

I went to our meeting appointed for Elizabeth Robinson from Old England whose testimony I thought the most searching that I ever hear in many branches and in particular to the foremost rank concerning treating with offenders in their own strength and own will, and mentioned the passage concerning some that attempted to cast out devils and the evil spirits to fell upon them and tore them and concerning some that assumed offices in the church that had no right. And it came so tight I was almost ready to wish I had never made any pretences to religion and I was somewhat disconsolate for several days but taking up a Bible one evening I opened on this verse: Let the righteous smite me it shall be a kindness: and let him reprove me, it shall be an excellent oil that shall not break my head, for yet my prayer also shall been in their calamities. Psalms the CXLI. 5th verse.Psalms 141:5 I remembered the wounds of a friend are said to be faithfulProverbs 27:6 and that them that are loved ones are chastened. After this I thought I was favored to see that this testimony was a favor if rightly minded and my mind was settled under it, and I clearly saw that we stood in great need of it. Her testimony was very close against a worldly spirit. concerning many, nay she said all, was more or less deeply fettered and in the miry stiff clay and that our garments was spotted but that there was some that was endeavoring to have those spots washed out, but some she said was bound down to the world as with iron chains. I was favored to see there was need of getting deeper.
I went to John Stone's to work
At ditto.
I went to our meeting preparative which was silent went to J Stone's after meeting
At work at Stone's.

Seventh Day of the week. I went to Evesham Meeting appointed for Robert Walker from Old England whose testimony was very large and searching in many respects. He told us of the many favors and warnings we had had and that, whether we would choose or refuse, the Lord would have a people; that he would call others in if we refused; and that the day was dawned that would never be totally eclipsed and that the indignation and wrath of the Almighty would be poured out on this land in a great degree if the people did not return; and that God would be clear and his servants would be clear and our blood would be on our own heads and was very close and plain with the foremost ranks and in particular respecting carrying Monthly Meeting business on in their own strength and own wills and I think he hinted that it was too much the cases in general in our land and spoke of many that were wounded and some that were quite dead and reminded us of the many warning that we have had and threatenings of wars and times of trouble and trials times past and of the Indian wars and of the cruel oppression of the Negroes in the southern provinces and that their cries were as ascended to heaven and said an overflowing scourge would come if it did come.

Robert Walker was at our meeting and a very great number of people met whose desires were too much after words and I thought we should have had a silent meeting but at length Robert appeared and said he did not expect to say much but reminded us of the many opportunities we have had and of the abundance of labor there had been flowed on us and to how little purpose in the general, and that he thought a famine at time would be best, but spoke very considerable concerning taking heed to the light and I thought his sermon was very suitable to the state of the people.
Eleventh Month, 1774. I went to John Stone's to work.
At ditto.
At ditto.

dateline.date: 10 I went to our Monthly Meeting.

div.p: Mark Reeve was there had a great deal to sat concerning an easeful state and how dangerous and like the people of Laish this easeful drowsy state was.
div.note: Very poor dull times with me

div.p: About home.
I went to the saw mill for a load of pine boards.

Went to our meeting. Mark Reeve was there and spoke first very encouraging to a mournful state and had a great deal to say to us and was very particular in speaking against an overzealous forward state that was like passionate lovers that could hardly endure the absence of the master or a winter season and mentioned the charge, I charge you by the rows and by the hind of the field that ye stir not up nor awake my beloved till he pleas.Song of Solomon 2:7
div.note: A very dull poor time with me

div.p: About home went with Joshua Roberts to look at a cow for beef.
About home my eyesight was at this time very much hurt by kindling of fire with some powder being a little burnt and then got cold in them so that I was hardly capable of any business.
Ditto.
I went to our meeting.
About home.

Ditto. This was the time friends set off to Salem Quarterly Meeting and I was so bad with my eyes I could not go and a very dull discouraging winter-like sort of a season it was with me both inwardly and outwardly. There seemed a dull poor prospect for me.
Went to our meeting.
div.note: Poor Tired? Dull times

div.p: I went to John Haines's to do a little work.
About home.
I went to Philadelphia to get something for my eyes.
About home. Making a bedstead for Samuel Collins.
Ditto ditto.
Ditto ditto.
Went to our meeting.
div.note: I thought not quite so poor as some time before

div.p: At home killing a beef etc.
I went to Barzila Coats to make a pump 16 feet long.

I went to Evesham Meeting to meet some Friends to consider some matters and in particular that of Friends running out in marriage. It being a very wet day but few met and concluded to meet the morning before next Monthly Meeting

p.del: 28 I went to our preparative meeting

div.p: I went to our preparative. Thomas Hooton and Atlantica Stokes was married Hannah Foster was there and spoke very extraordinary. I finished Coats's pump this evening.
I went to Ebenezer Hopkins's to make a pump 16 feet long.
At do finished and came home and heard of the death of my uncle Henry Wood, my mother's brother.
I went to our meeting Hannah Reeve was there and Esther Davis both spoke Hannah I thought was very notable and lively.
About home salting beef etc.
I went to make a pump for Thomas French.
At ditto.

I went to our Monthly Meeting. Samuel Lippincott was there and Ebenezer Miller and Hannah Reeve and all spoke and Joshua Evans all very well but I was very poor and seemed to be stripped quite naked. Hannah Reeve I thought touched my condition in her public service.
About home a wet day.
Getting firewood.
Went to our meeting. Samuel Lippincott and Ebenezer Miller was there and had a good deal to say which was edifying.

I killed hogs in the morning and went to Haddonfield Monthly Meeting. The above mentioned Friends was there and was lively in their ministry but I seemed to have no part with them. So poor and so stripped.
About home cutting up pork etc.
I went to hew pump for William Edgerton.
Helping John Haines kill hogs.
Putting axletrees in a wagon at home etc.
I went to put an old pump into a new well for John Cox it proved too short and did no good.

Went to our meeting which was silent. In Thomas Story's life I find these verses which he gave to an Irish Papist, page 555: Natural religion was simple first and plain, tales made it mystery, offerings made it gain, sacrifices and shews were at length prepared. The priests eat roast beef and the people star'd.
I went to make a pump for William Edgerton.
At ditto.
Ditto.
I went to our meeting. Rebekah Roberts spoke very well and with a true concern.
Was snowy weather.
Ditto. At work at a settle for John Haines.
Went to our meeting which to me was something better though silent.
About home- trying to hire a schoolmaster.
Went to work at Edgerton's pump.
There came a very great snow and beat us off.
I went to preparative meeting which was silent.
About home.
Ditto.
Was at our meeting which was silent.
At home in the morning and went to hew a sled for John Haines.
At John Haines at work at his sled
At ditto.
Went to Monthly Meeting Hannah Foster and Rebekah Roberts both spoke very well. I was favored to see I stood in great need of learning true stillness.
Finishing Haines sled.
Making a bedstead for Ann Burroughs and went to Haddonfield and to mill afternoon.
Went to our meeting. Joshua Evans was there and spoke very extraordinary in my opinion and touched my condition exactly in one point I thought. He came to my house after meeting.
I went to meet the overseers of the poor of Evesham and Northampton and others about some poor people. The time was not so disagreeable as I expected considering the company and at a tavern.
I went to finish William Edgerton's pump 50 feet long.
Finished it and came home.
Went to our meeting which was silent.
About home making a settle for John Haines.
At do getting firewood etc.
Went to our meeting which was silent and a poor hard meeting to me a great want of coming down deeper and more into stillness.
About home turning boxes for pumps etc.
Hewing a pump for our schoolhouse.
Snow though we bored the pump for the schoolhouse 22 feet long.
Went to our youth's meeting. Hannah Foster prayed very notably.
I went to meet the Justices, Overseers of the Poor and Representatives to bind some poor children and we bound four of them.
div.note: The time not very disagreeable though at a tavern the people being moderate beyond my expectation. Our reckoning for drink was but 6 a piece to me

div.p: Finishing the pump at our schoolhouse.
Went to our meeting which was silent and very poor.
I went to Barzillai Coats's get timber for plows
At home turning pump boxes etc.
I went to Hugh Hollinshead's to make him a pump 17 feet long. This evening I went to see my beloved friend and brother Aaron Wills which opportunity was very satisfactory.
I finished the pump and went to our meeting both Rebekah Roberts she expressed a concern that we might be enabled to stand in our lots if a trying time should be permitted.
I went to make a pump for Thomas Bishop X paid 45 feet long
Was very stormy I hewed another pump for Hezekiah Joy 24 feet long
Was First Day went to our meeting Rebekah Roberts spoke very well
div.note: A Very Poor Heavy Dul Meeting to me

div.p: About home turning pump boxes.
I went to Thomas Bishop's pump again.
At ditto.
At do I went to our preparative meeting and finished Thomas Bishop's pump- Rebecca Roberts very well.
div.note: A Very Poor Heavy Dull Meeting to me

div.p: I went to make Toy's pump 23 feet 8.
I finished it and came home.
I went to our meeting.
div.note: Very Poor and Dull

div.p: About home turning and I went to Edward French's in the afternoon.
At Edward French's making a pump 31 and a half feet long.
At do finished and came home next morning. At Edward French's I seemed to narrowly escape being badly hurt with the kick of a horse.
Went to our Monthly Meeting. Isaac Andrews, William and Benjamin Jones was there. Isaac and William was very lively in testimony.
About home turning boxes etc for pumps.
At ditto.
Went to our meeting. Thomas Say and his wife was there both appeared very well concerned for the future well being of us all.
I went to Haddonfield Monthly Meeting. John Tateum a young man spoke and Joshua Evans was remarkable in his testimony against the fashions of the times.
I went to Ephraim Haines's to mend his pumps.
Getting some stuff for moldboards for plows.
Went to our meeting. Thomas and wife was there both spoke very notably.
At home making the running gears for my wagon.
I went down to Benjamin Morgan's place to measure a very deep well.
Went to our meeting. It was silent. Joseph Buzby and his wife was here to see us.
I went to John Cowperthwaits the elder‘s burial. Isaac Andrews, Mercy Redman and Hannah Foster was there and all appeared. Mercy Redman was the most lively by far at that time.
div.note: A poor hard shut up time to me

div.p: About home very lame with a swelling on my hand.
About home and went to French's mill.
My wife and I went to the burial of Atlantic Stokes daughter of William Matlack married at our meeting about nine months ago and moved to Haddonfield. Isaac Andrews preached very extraordinary.
div.note: My hand was very bad.
Samuel Atkinson the elder was buried the same day at our meeting between 90 and 100 years old.
A very hard dull time to me till the meeting broke up and then I felt something of a humbling power to affect my spirits.

div.p: We went to Isaac Barton's and took a load of corn to his mill.
About home hauling fire wood.
Went to our meeting.
Went to Job Coles to mend his pump.
I went to Enoch Evans' to make a pump 30 feet.
At ditto.
Went to our preparative meeting.
div.note: Very Poor

div.p: About home.
I went to Isaac Borton's to get timber for a pump for Benjamin Morgan.
Went to our meeting.
div.note: Very Poor and heavy Time

div.p: About home.
I went to Reuben Braddock's to make a pump 22 feet long.
At ditto.
Went to our Monthly Meeting. Ebenezer Miller and William Jones was the and both spoke very lively and Hannah Foster also appeared but a dead dull heavy distressed dull time it was with me
About home finishing my wagon.
At ditto ditto.
Went to our meeting. R. Roberts spoke very well.
I went down to Philadelphia to and bought a servant lad off aboard a vessel.
I went to our general town meeting.
About home hauling out dung.

Robert Valentine and Josiah Bolindin was there from Pennsylvania was there. Robert spoke very close home to the state of our meeting in divers respects concerning the easeful dull slothful state of some and to some that had deserted the master's cause.
I went to Evesham meeting. Robert spoke very much in like manner as at our meeting.
At home.
Was First Day. My wife and I went over the creek to Ancocas meeting and there I met with some encouragement though the meeting was silent.
div.note: Went to Aaron's to lodge

div.p: We went Ancocas meeting appointed for Robert Valentine and he in like manner as at our meetings spoke though more favorable. His business seemed to be to strengthen and encourage the honest hearted and to stir up the slothful and drowsy that were set down at ease. We went to Joseph Busby's to dine and so home.
About home
Ditto.
Went up to Barton's mill.

We went to Quarterly Meeting at Haddonfield which I believe was a favored meeting. Robert Walker was there and Mary Lever both appeared very deeply concerned for the people. Also a man from York spoke in a very extraordinary manner and spoke along time.
div.note: But to me it was a shut up time seemingly

div.p: At work at home boring a pump for Benjamin Morgan.
I was at our meeting was very dark and dull.

I went to Philadelphia Spring meeting and went to Pine Street. Joseph Delaplain was there from York and spoke very largely concerning Naaman the leper who was Syrian and he spoke upon that chapter 2 Kings 5 and explained it in a most wonderful manner. He appeared to be a man of a very large gift and very highly favored after him. Ann Moore a choice old Friend from Maryland spoke in a very affecting manner and John Churchman spoke concerning prayer. Very instructing and we seemed to be highly favored with a lively tendering meeting for so it was to me.
About home at work at some plows and at Morgan's pump.
At ditto.
Went to our meeting preparative.
div.note: Very Poor

div.p: About home finishing a couple of plows one for J. Lippincott and one for Elisha Hooton.
About home at work.
Went to our meeting which was silent and Very Poor
About home.
Went to Elisha Hooton to make a pump.
At do rainy and did not finish it.
Went to Monthly Meeting. Hannah Foster spoke very notably.
I went to Jacob Stokes's to put a top piece on his pump 15 and 1/2 feet long [crossed out]
Ditto.
Went to our meeting.
About home turning pump boxes etc.
I went down to Woodbury to make 2 pumps for Aaron Hews one was 16 feet long and one 25 feet long long
At ditto.
At ditto.
Went to Woodbury meeting. Isaac Andrews spoke very extraordinary encouraging to such who had their faces Sion ward. Came home this evening.
About home turning pump boxes.
Went to our meeting.
About home and was with some people laying out a road.
Went to Thomas Stokes's to get some hay.
Went to Elisha Hooton's to finish a pump 22 feet long and get fish.
Went to our meeting it was youth's meeting Thomas Gill and Sarah Stokes was married Thomas Evans and Josiah White and Hannah Foster all spoke
div.note: I was unwell and a very poor time it was with me in the forepart of the meeting but latter part was better

div.p: About home finishing a pump for Jn Haines 22 feet long and dressing a calf.
About home.
Went to our meeting which was very dull and heavy.
Went to plowing.
Ditto.
Went to our meeting.
About home plowing.
Ditto.
Ditto.
Went to our Monthly Meeting.
div.note: plowing

div.p: About home at work.
Ditto.
Ditto.
Went to our Monthly Meeting. Ann Gaunt from Egg Harbor was there and spoke very notably.
About Job Coles' pump mending it.
At home plowing.
Went to our meeting Rebekah Roberts spoke very well.
I went down to Haddonfield Monthly Meeting. John Reeves was there and spoke pretty notable.
About home planting corn etc.
Ditto.
Went to our meeting which was silent and very dull.
At home making fence.
Was at Philadelphia market.
Was at our meeting. Rebecca Roberts spoke.
div.note: Very Poor

div.p: At home mending my wagon.
Ditto.
Ditto.
Went to our meeting. R Roberts spoke.
About home.
Set at for Salem Quarterly Meeting. My wife and her sister Elizabeth Haines lodged at Caleb Lippincott's.

Went to Piles Grove meeting. William Brown was there and spoke very lively and well. Afternoon we went to Salem afternoon meeting. Friend Brown was very exceeding lively in the ministry. Went to Richard Smith's to lodge.
Went to the Quarterly Meeting. William Brown was very notable and several others very lively in the ministry.
Was the Yearly Meeting. William Brown appeared again very zealous and applicable to the present times of commotion and wars. We came up to John Ballinger's to lodge.
We went to Piles Grove Youth's Meeting. William Brown and Isaac Andrews both spoke in a very extraordinary manner and then came home after meeting.
div.note: Very Dull Heavy Poor Time With Me

div.p: About home replanting corn.
Turning etc.
I went to hew stuff for a pump for B Morgan and did something at Thomas Lippincott's pump.
Went to our meeting. Mark Reeve and Hannah Foster both spoke very extraordinary.

Went to our meeting of conference concerning the troubles and confusions of the times.Journal adds Great excitement seems to prevail among the powers of the earth, and in the minds of the people, 224. Mark Reeve had a great deal to say and several others spoke to it very notably.
About home at work at Morgan's pump.
I went to the doctor for our little daughter Rachel who was taken with the flux or purging and vomiting.
Went to our preparative meeting. Rebekah Roberts spoke.
About home our child was very bad and died with the flux about 9 o'clock in the morning.
of the Sixth Month 1775 We buried our little daughter Rachel. We had the company of Friends Aaron Wills and wife.
Went to our meeting which was exceeding great confusion seemed to arise in the powers of the Earth and among the people.
div.note: Dark dull and heavy in my apprehension

div.p: About home our daughter Abby was very bad with the flux.
About ditto.
About ditto.
Ditto. Was Monthly Meeting. I could not go the child was bad.
div.note: I T N S T a a S T

div.p: Ditto.
Ditto.
Went to our meeting.
About home.
At work at Morgan's pump.
I went to mend a pump for Catey Lippincott.
Went to our meeting. Elizabeth Atkinson spoke.
div.note: P T w m

div.p: Making a plow for Samuel Burroughs.
I went to put in the long pump for Morgan.
Went to the burial of Joseph Warrington's daughter Rebekah about four years old, died with the flux.
Went to help John Roberts raise his house.
Went to make a top piece pump for Joseph Roberts 14 feet long.
I went to take up Morgan's pump.
Made a plow for Jonas Cattle.

Went to our meeting under great discouragement. Rebekah Roberts spoke. Hannah Foster was there and spoke exact to my condition very fully concerning the ebbings and flowings of the waters compatible to the fellings of our minds which sometimes were tried with deep ebbing and said they that had business upon them must go down into the deep. It was a heart tendering time to me and great encouragement in a drooping time when hope had almost failed and the tempter strove hard to prevail.
I went to put Morgan's pump in the well again got it accomplished to satisfaction the pump 71 feet long.
Went to our meeting.
About home.
I went to Enoch Evans' to do something at his pump.
At Borton's mill.
Went to our preparative meeting and mend and old pump for William Cox 15 shillings.
At home reaping.
At reaping.
Went to our meeting. I thought it was something more agreeable.
Reaping home.
Ditto.
Ditto rainy day.
Was Monthly Meeting. Hannah Foster was very lively in prayer.
Hauling in our rye and wheat.
I went down to Philadelphia and settled with Benjamin Morgan. His pump iron work all came to £3.5- 6
Went to our meeting.
Went to moving.
Ditto and making hay.
Ditto.
Went to our meeting.
About moving and hay.
Ditto.
Went to our meeting.
div.note: Very Poor Time

div.p: Met with our Friends to raise money to send to relieve our Friends at Boston.
About hay.
About home ditto.
I went to our youth's meeting at Evesham. Caleb Lippincott and Zilpha Shin was married. Hannah Foster was very lively and notable in ministry.
div.note: A very Poor Heavy Dul Mettin

div.p: I went to make a pump for Caleb Evans 23 feet long.
I was with my wife and children up at Isaac Borton's and we went to get huckleberry of which there was great plenty.
Went to our meeting. After meeting Jacob Holinshad and myself on appointment from the Monthly Meeting to visit Thomas Lippincott on account of his drinking to excess to very little satisfaction.
About home making a plow etc.
Ditto. About home
Ditto.
Went to our meeting.
div.note: Very Poor and Dull And heavy

div.p: Making an apple mill at home.
Ditto.
Went to our meeting.
At home finishing an apple mill.
Ditto.
At work at another apple mill.
I went to our preparative meeting which seemed to me to be chiefly naught.
I went to fix an old pump in a new well for Joy Smith at Moorestown.
About home. Rain. I with our schoolmaster went to see our Friend Joshua Evans who was under trials and affliction.
We went to Newtown Meeting. A very stormy day. Isaac Zane from Philadelphia was there and spoke very well but it was a very dull heavy time with me.
I went to hew a pump for Thomas Thorn.
About home at work at an apple mill for Elisha Hooton and one for myself.
At ditto.
Went to our monthly meeting which was silent and Poor and Dull.
At home at work at apple mills.
div.note: I thought I felt rather better in my meditations when in my business

div.p: Ditto.
Went to our meeting. William Jones was there and spoke very notable close and plain to the dull drowsy condition of many of us.
div.note: A Dull Drowsy Heavy Meeting it Was With me

div.p: I went to make a bottom piece to Richard Smith's 22 feet long.
At home making plows for Joseph Roberts.
Turning pump boxes and making a pump for Thomas Thorn.
I went to Isaac Borton's to make two pumps to stand at the tail of his mill
To throw water back to his pond. Each 11 feet feet long.
Went to our meeting. Rebekah Roberts spoke.
div.note: A Very Poor Time to me

div.p: I went to Job Coles to mend his pump in the morning. Afternoon I went down to Jacob Jennings's to make a screw press and apple mill.
At ditto.
Ditto.
I went Haddonfield meeting which was silent and very dark and dull.
At work at the press and mill at Jenning's.
At do and took up his pump finished all of came home.

Went to our meeting. Mary Horner from Burlington Quarter and another woman Friend from Egg Harbor was there. James Willis his wife. They both seemed to have a very clear sight and sense of the easeful poor dwarfish condition of our meeting and seemed very much concerned and both spoke very notable close and plain to the state of our meeting.
I went to work at a screw press for myself.
At ditto.
Ditto.
I went to our preparative meeting.
div.note: R. Roberts spoke but it was heavy dull times with me

div.p: At work at a screw press for myself.
Ditto. This week I had several fits of something like the fever and ague.
This week was very wet and cloudy and Seventh Day night was a most dismal stormy dark rainy night, with great wind rain and thunder which blowed down the corn very flat and some apple trees.
Went to our meeting.
div.note: Very Poor

div.p: Finishing my own screw press.
I went to Jacob Hollinshead's to take up his pump in order to dig his well deeper and went to Joshua Bispham's to take up his pump to make the timber hobs lower
I was at Thomas Lippincott's to mend his pump which was very troublesome by reason of their letting an old tumbler fall in it.
We went to our Monthly Meeting. Hannah Foster spoke very extraordinary.
div.note: but a poorish meeting though I thought something better than at some times

div.p: Trimming some casks and about cider.
Made about five barrels of cider.
I went to our meeting which was silent but it was a good tender meeting to me and considerably encouraging my heart being tendered and broken. An epistle was read at the close of the meeting

I went down to Haddonfield Monthly Meeting. Mercy Redman spoke very well in meeting of Business. I was very much dissatisfied with their dealings with Jos Evans and said something on his behalf for which they reproved me, though it did not trouble me at all for I thought it was clear to me they did not treat with him in a right spirit.
I went to Richard Smith's about an old pump which I had abundance of trouble with before I could make it tight.
I went to putt Jacob Hollinshead pump down in his well again.
Went to our meeting which was silent.
div.note: Very Poor J and Heavy

div.p: I was at home making a safe for Elizabeth Haines.
My wife and I was at town.
Went to our meeting. Rebekah Roberts spoke a few words.
div.note: a hard sort of a meeting

div.p: At home making a safe for Elizabeth Haines.

I went to Evesham Meeting appointed for Mary Horner and Hannah Wilson. Hannah was a young woman from Pennsylvania and very large and lively in the ministry. Mary seemed to have very hard labor with the foremost rank and elderly people. She was exceeding close and plain.
Those Friends was at our meeting and spoke encouraging to some of the rising generation but to the elderly sort they were very smart and plain.
About home making a floor in the kitchen.

We went to Haddonfield Quarterly Meeting where there was a very large gathering and a large number of very substantial Friends. Ann Ga[u]nt from Egg Harbor seemed to have pretty much the weight of that day's service upon her and spoke twice very notably. Mary Horner also spoke concerning the love of money as a particular stumbling block amongst that people. Several others also spoke.
div.note: the meeting this week at Evesham and Chester to me was pretty good and tender and edifying and encouraging but at Haddonfield it was very hard and poor

div.p: About home laying floor in the kitchen etc.
Was First Day. I was at our meeting and went to Joshua Evans' in the afternoon.

We went from his house on foot over to town to the Yearly Meeting and I went to Pine Street meeting where there was many lively testimonies delivered and it was something tendering to me. In the afternoon was at the same meeting and began business about the 3 hour afternoon and continued till Seventh Day late at night. I was unwell this week with the fever and ague yet I attended till about 10 the last sitting but one. This I thought was a very good week's schooling to much diligence and making a new beginning in religion. Old Thomas Gathrop was there from Old England but was almost altogether silent.
I went to our meeting the poorly Josiah White and Benjamin Jones was there. Josiah spoke pretty notably not so poor as at sometimes. We went to see Elisha Hooton in the afternoon.
Making cider. Had the Third Day ague.
At home about corn husking.
Ditto.
I went to our Monthly Meeting. Had the ague again. Ann Jessup and Esther Hunt daughter of Ebenezer Hunt from Carolina was there. Ann spoke very notably which was something tendering.
About home very unwell.
Seventh Day.

Was First Day. I went to our meeting. My friends Ann Jessup and cousin Esther Hunt was there. Ann had but little to say they came home with us and we had a pretty full account from our cousin William Hunt's widow and her children which was very satisfactory. I was very bad with the fever and ague when these friends was there which deprived me of their company and they with some friend from Philadelphia went from here to Haddonfield Monthly Meeting.
About home about the Indian Corn.
Ditto.
Ditto.
Went to our meeting with the children.
About our corn.
At ditto.
Was at our meeting which was silent.
Went to the burial of Mary Coles and had a meeting at Haddonfield. Mercy Redman spoke very notably and Isaac Andrews spoke also very smartly to the hypocrites and sinners in Sion.
About home very unwell with the fever and ague every Third Day.
Ditto. About sowing.
About home very poorly. Gathering winter apples and went to our youth's meeting. Thomas Evans spoke very well.
About home very poorly with the Third Day ague fever.
div.note: and I was Under S N A S A f A C Time I thought I Had prety Co But Put it of

div.p: Ditto.
Ditto.
Ditto.
Ditto.
Ditto.
Ditto.
Ditto.
Ditto.
About home very unwell with the fever and ague.
Ditto.
Ditto.
Ditto.
Ditto.
Ditto.
Ditto.
Went to our meeting which was not so dull to me as at some times.
I went to Joseph Hewlings's to make a pump 18 feet long. My sister Abigail Evans was there very bad with a fever. I came home.
At home unwell.
I went Hewling's again to finish the pump.

dateline.date: 9 We went to our Monthly Meeting.

div.p: John Reeves was there and spoke very notably and I thought he touched my condition which afforded some confirmation and encouragement. We went after meeting to see my sister who then lay very ill of a fever.
Came home.
About home unwell.

Ditto. Went up to Evesham Meeting with Joshua Evans who was at our house all Seventh Day night. Isaac Andrews was there and Ebenezer Miller both preached considerably. Thomas Eves was buried after meeting Joshua Evans and I went to see my sister Abby who was then getting better.
div.note: A Very Poor Dull Meeting to me

div.p: I went to Rendal Cales after some sheep which I bought of him.
At Coles mending his pump.
Went to work at a settle for Elizabeth Haines.
Went to our meeting. Jonas Cattle and Elizabeth Roberts was married. Isaac Andrews was there and spoke very exact to my state of poverty and encouragingly.
At work at the settle.
Went up to Borton's frs first? and I went to mend Daniel Lippincott's pump.
Was First Day and I had the fever and ague again.
At work at the sittle.
Ditto.
Ditto.
I was at our meeting. Hugh Hollinshead and Elener French was married. Mercy Redman was there and spoke very well.
We went to Burlington to take the settle and safe. Lodged at J. Buzby's.
We came home.
Went to our meeting.
About home.
Ditto.
Ditto.
Was at our preparative meeting.
About home.
I went to hew a tree for a pump for Hugh Cowperthwaite.
Was at our meeting.
Killing hogs.
Salting pork etc.
Went to Cowperthwaite's about the pump.
Went to our Monthly Meeting.
At Cowperthwaite's.
Went to Coles to fetch some sheep I bought of him.
Was at our meeting.
I went to finish a pump for Hugh Cowperthwaite 16
At ditto.
Hauling work at home.
Went to our meeting. Josiah White was there and preached very well.
I went to mend a pump for Joseph Hackney.
About home.
Went to our meeting. Rebekah Roberts spoke very prettily.

dateline.date: 18 Went to our meeting appointed for Elizabeth Brown from Wilmington, Hannah Foster and Mary both spoke very notably.

div.p: Mary seemed to have very hard work of it and her testimony was against a worldly spirit that is disposed to lay up treasures on earth. At this time the 17th of this Month and First Day Isaac Andrews was buried at Woodbury.
About home.
Ditto.
Ditto. Went to our meeting.
Ditto.
Ditto.
A violent stormy snowy day. I went to our meeting.
About home.
Ditto.
Ditto.
Was at our preparative meeting.
About home.
Ditto.
Ditto.
I went to Joshua Lippincott's to mend his pump.
I went to John Pine's to mend his pump 3 about home.
I was at our Monthly Meeting. H Foster spoke in a very lively manner. Josiah White spoke and Thomas Evans.
About home
I was at our meeting
I went over Ancocas Creek to fetch my wife's sister Elizabeth.
About home.
Ditto.
This morning my wife was brought to bed with a son about three o‘clock.
About mending a pump for Caty Lippincott.

I went to our meeting appointed for Joshua Brown and Thomas Vickers and they both preached in a very lively and affectionate manner. Thomas his testimony was much against a worldly spirit that was for laying up treasures on earth but Joshua was concerning the wars and troubles of the times.
I went to Evesham meeting. Joshua and Thomas was there and both preached most exceeding notably lively and powerful.
I went up to Caleb Evans' to hew a pump for Joshua Hunt.
At home at work at Joshua's pump.
Ditto.
Went to our meeting and was disappointed. It was youth's meeting at Evesham.
About home at work at Joshua's pump 43 feet long.
Ditto.
Went to our meeting was silent.
About home my wife was very bad with the pleurisy.
Finishing Joshua's pump.
Went to Moorestown to take the pump at put it in.

Went to our meeting. Rebekah Roberts spoke very prettily and I thought it seemed for me and it did me good. Her word was concerning the dry bones in the open valley.Ezekiel 37:1-2 and concerning the live coal from the holy altarIsaiah 6:6
At home my wife was very bad.
Ditto.
Was at our meeting.
About home.
Ditto.
Ditto.
I was at our preparative meeting.
I went to fetch the doctor for my wife.
About home.
Was at our meeting which was silent and very poor.
About.
Ditto.
Ditto.

Went to our Monthly Meeting.Evesham Monthly Meeting minutes, February 1776. The Case of Slavery coming under Consideration and by a letter from Jonathan Austen signifying he did not Incline to Comply with the Advice of the Committee of the Quarterly Meeting. Therefore William Foster's, Isaac Evans, Edward Darnell, John Lippincott, William Matlack, and John Hunt, are appointed to Treat with him and any other members that have Slaves, in order if possible, to convince them of the Inconsistency of holding them in Bondage, and Endeavor to procure suitable Learning for those that are Children in order to Qualify them for Freedom Justly Due to them. Mark Reeve was there and Josiah Miller. Both spoke.
div.note: the meeting was very dull and lifeless to me

div.p: I went to mend a pump for John Pine.
I went to see Daniel Packer who was like to die.

I went to our meeting. Mark Reeve was there and spoke concerning John being cast into prison and sends his disciples to Christ: Art thou he that should come or do we look for another. Matthew 11:3, Luke 7: 19
div.note: We were favored with a good meeting.

div.p: I went to Haddonfield Monthly Meeting which was very dark and poor and very tedious and tiresome.
I went to the burial of Daniel Packer.
I went to Kendal Coles to make a pump or new top piece.
Was at our meeting. Joseph Buzby and wife came home with me.
Went up to Micajah Wills's to meet J. Eldrige.
I was at Coles at work at the pump.
I was at our meeting which was silent and very poor.
I went to Coles to finish the new pump 13 feet long and take up the old one.
div.note: The ancient testimony of Friends was read.

div.p: I went to Edmund Hollinshead's to make a pump 43 feet long.
I went to our meeting. Rebekah Roberts spoke very prettily.
Went to Hollinshead to work at his pump.
At do finished and came home this evening.
I went to our meeting where we had more preaching than enough. Joseph Mittin I thought was there.

I went Burlington Quarterly where there was many young Friends appeared which seemed not altogether satisfactory. The meeting in the end was satisfactory to me instructing and something tendering. I lodged at my dear friend and brother Aaron Wills's where I had good satisfaction.
Came home.
I went to Burlington to take my wife's sister home.
I was at our preparative meeting R B Sr a cold poor time.
About home.
Ditto.
Was at our meeting which was silent though not so poor.
I went to William Rudrow's to hew a pump 14 feet long
I went to the burial of William Hooton. Josiah White was there and preached considerably.
About home turning pump boxes etc.
I went to the burial of Priscilla Evans, wife of Joshua. Samuel Hopkins was there and spoke very well. Mercy Redman spoke very well.
I went to William Rudrow's to finish his pump finished and came home.
At home trimming orchard etc.

I went to our meeting. Elizabeth Atkins was there and spoke. The meeting something tender. George Fox his words concerning James Naylor, Fox's Journal page 205. He says James Naylor was a monument of human frailty. His gift in the ministry was eminent his experience in divine things truly great. He fell through unwatchfulness, but was restored through deep suffering and unfeigned repentance. His own writings are the most clear and lively description of the various dispensations he underwent. Some of them deserve to be transmitted to the latest posterity.
div.note: Was First Day

div.p: Went to mill.
About home.
Ditto.
Went to our meeting.
At home.
Went to splice a pump for James Lippincott.
I Went to our meeting. Benjamin Sharples was there and spoke very well.
I went to the blacksmith's.

Went to our meeting. Thomas Gawthrop from Old England was there and spoke very extraordinary. He spoke concerning the rich man and LazarusLuke 16: 19-31 and told us we had one that spoke to us that was risen from the dead he appeared exceeding tenderhearted. Nicholas Waln and John Pemberton also spoke. The meeting seemed pretty tender and open.
About home
Ditto.

Went to Quarterly Meeting at Haddonfield. Thomas Gathrop spoke at the latter part of the meeting concerning a garden, a garden enclosed is my sister, my spouse and spoke of several sort of enclosures one was of death and poverty another of the grave and one of faith confidence hope etc. His ministry was exceeding lively and affecting.
About home making a screw press for Thomas Folwel.
Went to our meeting which was silent.

Joseph Roberts and I went down to town to the Spring meeting and went to the Big Meeting House. Elizabeth Brown and George Dillwyn spoke. Elizabeth said she had been dipped into a state that was in prison and mentioned the passage concerning John being cast into prison sending his disciples to Christ etc.Matthew 11:3, Luke 7: 19 George said he believed the call of the Lord was to them who had known something of the operation of truth time past and had too much swerved aside. Both testimonies seemed to touch my condition a very good tender meeting it was to me.
I went to help for John Haines move.
About home.
Making a plow for myself.
Making a plow for John Haines.

I was at Evesham Meeting which was small and poor, most of the elders being prevented by sickness. After meeting John Lippincott, William Matlack and I went to see Jonathan Ostin on account of a Negro he had. The time not disagreeable.
div.note: Not so dull a time to me as some others

div.p: About home making plows etc.
Ditto.
Ditto.
Went to our Monthly Meeting. Samuel Emlen and Mercy Redman was there and both spoke. The meeting for business was satisfactory and encouraging a little.
div.note: I was with these friends at John Evan's and at Esther Eldrige's and they both spoke

div.p: About home.

At home. Mercy Redman and Samuel Emlen was here on a family visit to our meeting and both spoke. Samuel's subject was concerning Abraham's faithfulness. His words was comfortable and encouraging but Mercy's subject was almost altogether concerning a forward busy spirit that would assume offices in the church that the great Master never intended for them which I could hardly think was right altogether and we went to Elisha Hooton's afternoon and I was after some strugglings of mind on the road favored with an exceeding heart melting tendering time and a Christian disposition and temper.
Was at our meeting Mercy Redman spoke.
At work at home.
Making a plow for Joseph Pearson.
About home.
Went to our meeting. James Witkins and Ann Holishead was married. Samuel Emlen and Mercy Redman both spoke very notably.
At work at some screws.
Ditto.
Was at our meeting Samuel Emlen and Mercy Redman both preached very extraordinary.
div.note: These opportunities was something tendering at home at times but I thought it was like a borrowed loaf or a morning dew which soon passes away.

div.p: Making a plow for Isaac Borton.
Ditto and about home.
I went down to Dock Vanleer.

Was at our meeting youth's meeting. Hannah Foster spoke in a very lively zealous well concerned affecting manner. She reminded us how easy it was for providence to evade the stroke or divert the storm that hangs over us and said she thought these would be some raised to stand for truth's cause whither we chose or refuse.
div.note: A very lively meeting. R. Roberts spoke very prettily.

div.p: About home.
Ditto.
Went to our meeting.
Went to plow for corn.
Ditto.
Ditto.
Was at our meeting and hard beset to get along. I was under such discouragement.
Plowing.
Ditto.
Was at our meeting.
At plow.
Ditto.
Plowing.
Was at our preparative meeting. Hannah Foster was there and spoke very extraordinary and a time of favor.
At plow.
Ditto.
Was at our meeting.
I went to William Foster's to mend his pump.
About home getting ready to plant and I went with Joshua Evans to see an old Negro woman that was very poorly and he prayed and preached very notably from there to Thomas Dudley.
Ditto. Making a plow for Barzila Coats.
Was at Monthly Meeting. Hannah Foster prayed very notably.
About home.
Planting.
I went to our meeting.
About home planting etc.
Ditto.
I set forward for Salem Quarterly Meeting with John Collins. We was at Upper Greenwich meeting. Dined at Solomon Lippincott's. I went to Caleb Lippincott's to lodge.
div.note: the meeting was but dull

div.p: Went to Salem Quarterly Meeting. Lodged at Benjamin Wright's.
At the Yearly Meeting at Salem. These meetings were favored with a very lively ministry.
We came up to John Barn's to lodge and so to Piles Grove Youth's Meeting which was very much favored with a lively edifying ministry and very satisfactory in the end and I came home after Meeting.
I went to our meeting which was a very tender good meeting to me. Rebekah Roberts spoke very prettily and about Jonah's troubles and I was favored at that time.
About home.
Ditto.
Went to our meeting which was indifferent well with me.
About home.
div.note: Felt something more stayed and composed.

div.p: Ditto.
Ditto.
Was at our preparative meeting which was but dull at first.
About home.
About home.
Was First Day. Was at our meeting. Thomas Say was there and spoke very well and his wife also appeared in prayer very notable.
About home making plows.

Was at our Monthly Meeting. Phebe Miller from Pennsylvania was there and a very sincere honest woman she appeared to be and spoke very notably. Ebenezer Miller spoke a considerable time. The meeting on the whole seemed well.
About home making and mending plows.
We went to Ancocas meeting which was dull. Dined at Aaron Wills's
